bibl.title: Letter from Harper Peddicord to Mabel H. Lazear, December 20, 1935

div1.p: Peddicord requests information to write an article about the life of Jesse Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Harper Peddicord to Mabel H. Lazear, December 20, 1935
div1.opener:
REDWOOD CITY
California
December Twentieth
1 9 3 5
Mrs. J. W. Lazear,
Cloyne Court Hotel,
2600 Ridge Road,
Berkeley, California.
My dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
I am taking this opportunity to tell you what great satis-
faction my recent short visit with you gave me.

Unfortunately, it has not been my privilege to see Doctor
Kelly's book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”, and I find that the
San Francisco Public Library does not have a copy on its shelves,
so I am wondering if you might possess a copy of this book. I
wish very much to read it.

As I have revolved this subject in my mind over the past two
years, I can understand readily why Walter Reed was on that board;
why James Carroll would be on the board; and considering the loca-
tions of their operations and his immunity why Aristides Agramonte
was on the board also. Therefore, the only reason that I can in my
own mind assign for Jesse W. Lazear on this board was that he was
particularly well versed, schooled and trained in that type of work.

I therefore wish to state that some time in the not too distant
future, and with your permission, it would give me a great deal of
pleasure to come out with an article that might have something truth-
ful and pertinent to say about Jesse W. Lazear, and yellow fever.

You must have in your possession some correspondence that would
be helpful in a work of this kind. This is more in the nature of a
suggestion to you, as I would like to get your reaction on this
matter.

Only two nights ago, I went over a portion of the corres-
pondence and manuscripts which Mr. Peabody sent me, and can only
acknowledge to you that I was rather lost in admiration, both in
the labors and the courage that he displayed over such a long period
of time.

It just now occurs to me that you might have a copy of Doctor
Kelly's book. If so, I would much like to have it for a day or so,
as it will save me sending to the Surgeon General's Library in
Washington, which would take a matter of weeks.
Again stating my pleasure in meeting you, and wishing always to remain,
